results.title: Film noir
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Schon, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American cinema”.
These cynical and pessimistic films from the 1930’s and 1940’s touched a raw nerve in Americans. Historians link the genre’s overriding paranoia to Cold War related angst over the nuclear threat and the Hollywood blacklist. Additionally, a cinematographer demonstrates the creation of lighting which gives these films their peculiar look thus emphasising the themes of corruption and urban decay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeffrey Schon, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History

results.title: Film making
results.brief_description: Films designed for school orientated learning have brought a new impact and excitement to learning previously unavailable in the classroom. In this investigation, the actual production of such a film is followed from beginning to finished product. It goes from covering the idea, script, costing, cameraman, director, crew, actors, titles, lettering, animation, editing, narration and music.

results.title: Film in the television age
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Foster, Alain Klarer, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American cinema”.
Television arrived in American homes just as the Hollywood studio system was collasping. As the new medium took hold, so did a new era in motion picture entertainment. Renown directors, film scholars and actors trace the influence of each medium upon the other; from the live and fresh dramas of the Golden Age of Television and the growth of Hollywood spectacles to the modern day megalithic entertainment industry.

results.title: Film graphics: abstract aspect of editing
results.creator_credit: Barry Spinello, Paul Aratow and Cine Qua Non-Bartholomus
results.brief_description: With pictures, animation and quotations from classical cinema, this film shows some of the basic structural principles of film composition and editing. Extracts from BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN, UN CHIEN ANDALOU, and MAN WITH A MOVIE CAMERA, show the use of abstract graphic structure in film editing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Spinello, Paul Aratow and Cine Qua Non-Bartholomus
